item.title: Assimilating the Southern Annular Mode
item.description: We’re reconstructing the Southern Annular Mode (SAM) over the Common Era by applying data assimilation to drought atlases and the PAGES network of temperature sensitive climate proxies. The SAM is a major influence on Southern Hemisphere climate, and has impacts on storm tracks, drought, and ice melt. Understanding its past variations can help characterize its behavior and predict its response to future climate change.

item.title: LGM Reconstructions
item.description: We’re using data assimilation to constrain climate reconstructions of the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). Check out Jess Tierney’s paper, which uses reconstructed SSTs at the LGM to constrain ECS, and Matt Osman’s new reconstruction of surface temperatures from the LGM to present.

item.title: Volcanic Assimilations
item.description: We’re using data assimilation to examine the sensitivity of the climate system to volcanic eruptions throughout the Common Era. Check out Feng Zhu’s recent papers probing discrepancies between reconstructions and models and testing the ENSO response to volcanism.

item.title: DASH
item.description: DASH is a Matlab package that facilitates paleoclimate data assimilation workflows. It includes utilities to build and organize state vectors, estimate proxy values using proxy system models (PSMs), and implement Ensemble Kalman Filters, Particle Filters, and Optimal Sensor tests. It has been used to implement a number of recent scientific studies.

item.title: NTREND Assimilation
item.description: We’re reconstructing surface temperatures in the Northern Hemisphere over the last millennium using data assimilation. This project focuses on the NTREND network, an expert-curated selection of temperature-sensitive tree ring records.

item.title: Glacial cooling and climate sensitivity revisited
Resolving the differences in the simulated and reconstructed climate response to volcanism over the last millennium
A data assimilation approach to last millennium temperature field reconstruction using a limited high-sensitivity proxy network
Globally resolved surface temperatures since the Last Glacial Maximum
Volcanoes and ENSO: a re-appraisal with the Last Millennium Reanalysis
